#Text=Thomas Ruthall
#Text=For Thomas Ruthall ( MP ) , see Preston ( UK Parliament constituency ) .
#Text=Thomas Ruthall ( also spelled Ruthal , Rowthel or Rowthall ; died 4 February 1523 ) was an English churchman , administrator and diplomat .
#Text=He was a leading councillor of Henry VIII of England . [ 1 ]
#Text=Education and early career
#Text=He was born at Cirencester .
#Text=He was educated at the University of Oxford , ordained a deacon on 10 April 1490 at Worcester , and incorporated DD at Cambridge in 1500 .
#Text=Before this date he had entered the service of Henry VII of England .
#Text=In June 1499 , then described as prothonotary , he went on an embassy to Louis XII of France , and on his return occupied the position of king 's secretary . [ 2 ] [ 3 ]
#Text=Church and court career
#Text=Ruthall had a long series of ecclesiastical preferments .

#Text=In 1495 he had the rectory of Bocking , Essex ( whose priest is called the Dean of Bocking ) , in 1502 he became a prebendary of Wells , and in 1503 Archdeacon of Gloucester , Dean of Salisbury and chancellor of Cambridge .
#Text=In 1505 he was made prebendary of Lincoln ; Henry VII , who had already made him a privy councillor , appointed him Bishop of Durham in 1509 , but Henry died before Ruthall was consecrated .
#Text=Henry VIII confirmed his appointment , and continued him in the office of secretary .
#Text=He was part of the skeleton council that accompanied Henry VIII to the Tower of London at the beginning of his reign , following the death of Henry VII . [ 4 ]
#Text=In 1510 , with Richard Foxe and Thomas Howard , Earl of Surrey , he negotiated a fragile peace with France . [ 2 ] [ 5 ]
#Text=He went to France with the king in 1513 with a hundred men , but was sent back to England when James IV of Scotland threatened war .
#Text=He took a part in the preparations for defence , strengthened Norham Castle , and wrote to Thomas Wolsey after the Battle of Flodden ( 1513 ) .
#Text=He was present at the marriage of Louis XII and the Princess Mary Tudor in 1514 , and in 1516 was made Lord Privy Seal . [ 2 ]
#Text=In 1518 he was present when Wolsey was made a papal legate , and was one of the commissioners when the Princess Mary was betrothed to the Dauphin , Francis III , Duke of Brittany .
#Text=He was at the Field of the Cloth of Gold in 1520 , and was again at Calais with Wolsey in 1521 .
#Text=When Buckingham was examined by the king , Ruthall was present as secretary .
#Text=A hardworking official , he did a great deal of the interviewing necessary in diplomatic negotiations .
#Text=Brewer represents him as Wolsey 's drudge , and Giustinian speaks of his " singing treble to the cardinal 's bass . "
#Text=He died on 4 February 1523 at Durham Place , London , and was buried in St John 's Chapel , Westminster Abbey . [ 2 ]
#Text=Legacy
#Text=As a benefactor he repaired the bridge at Newcastle , and built a great chamber at Bishop Auckland .
#Text=He also increased the endowment of the grammar school at Cirencester which had been established by John Chedworth , in 1460 . [ 2 ]
#Text=He was a patron of Erasmus . [ 6 ]
#Text=Thomas More was a colleague in government , and a friend , and dedicated his edition of Lucian to Ruthall . [ 7 ]
#Text=Styles and titles
#Text=1490 – bef .
#Text=1493 : The Reverend Thomas Ruthall
#Text=bef .
#Text=The Reverend Doctor Thomas Ruthall
#Text=The Very Reverend Doctor Thomas Ruthall
#Text=The Very Reverend and Right Honourable Doctor Thomas Ruthall
#Text=The Right Reverend and Right Honourable Doctor Thomas Ruthall
